# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 904, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 240, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[777, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 390, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 650]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 212, 694]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 696, 728, 727]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
1 A crate is being pushed in a straight line along a horizontal surface by a force of magnitude 25 N inclined at \(20^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. The crate moves a distance of 12 m in 8 seconds with constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 136, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 135, 440, 153]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the constant speed of the crate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 352, 144, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 351, 454, 369]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the work done by the 25 N force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 723, 144, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 721, 555, 740]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the power at which the 25 N force is working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
2 Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses 0.2 kg and 0.1 kg respectively, are free to move in a straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. \(P\) is projected towards \(Q\) with speed 5 m s \(^{-1}\). At the same instant, \(Q\) is projected away from \(P\) with speed 2 m s \(^{-1}\). When \(P\) collides with \(Q\), the particles coalesce.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 494, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the kinetic energy lost during the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
3

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 81, 692, 191]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 210, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length 2.6 m . The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point on a horizontal ceiling, and the string is taut. The particle is held in equilibrium by a force of magnitude 35 N , acting in a vertical plane which is perpendicular to the ceiling and contains the string. The force acts in a direction perpendicular to the string (see diagram). The tension in the string is \(T \mathrm{~N}\) and the vertical distance of \(P\) from the ceiling is 2.4 m .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 304, 546, 322]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the value of \(m\) and the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 139]]<|/det|>
4 A car is travelling along a straight horizontal road. The car passes through a point \(A\), on the road travelling at a speed of \(15 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\), and then accelerates uniformly at \(0.4 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) for 30 seconds. The car then moves at constant speed for \(37 \mathrm{~seconds}\), where \(T<30\). The car then decelerates uniformly at \(0.2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) and after a further \(T\) seconds passes through a point \(B\) on the road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 154, 144, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 153, 878, 170]]<|/det|>
(a) On the given axes, sketch a velocity-time graph for the motion of the car between points \(A\) and \(B\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 183, 784, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 441, 400, 458]]<|/det|>
The distance from \(A\) to \(B\) is 2750 m .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 473, 144, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 472, 313, 489]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 477, 918, 508]]<|/det|>
<pre>The car continues its journey from \(B\), decelerating uniformly at \(0.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) until it comes to rest at a point \(C\) on the road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 523, 144, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 522, 435, 540]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the total distance from \(A\) to \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
5

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 87, 772, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 918, 323]]<|/det|>
One end of a light inextensible string is attached to a particle \(A\) of mass 3 kg . The other end of the string is attached to a particle \(B\) of mass 4 kg . Particle \(A\) is in contact with a rough plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal, and particle \(B\) is in contact with a smooth horizontal plane. A second light inextensible string is attached to \(B\). The other end of this second string is attached to a particle \(C\) of mass 5 kg which hangs vertically.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 337, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
Both strings are taut and pass over small smooth pulleys that are fixed at the ends of the horizontal plane. The part of the string from \(A\) to the pulley is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the inclined plane, and \(A, B\) and \(C\) are in the same vertical plane (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 399, 918, 430]]<|/det|>
The system is released from rest. In the subsequent motion, \(C\) moves vertically downwards with acceleration \(2 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\), and neither \(A\) nor \(B\) reach a pulley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 445, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 463, 462]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the tensions in each of the strings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 660, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the coefficient of friction between \(A\) and the inclined plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 720, 369]]<|/det|>
<pre>When the system has been in motion for 1.5 s , the string attached to \(A\) breaks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 383, 144, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 382, 918, 414]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the total distance that \(A\) travels up the plane from the instant that the system is released from rest to the instant that \(A\) comes to instantaneous rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 915, 110]]<|/det|>
6 A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line and passes through the point \(A\) at time \(t=0\). The velocity \(v \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) of \(P\) at time \(t\) seconds is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 120, 643, 141]]<|/det|>
\[
\nu=(2 t+1)^{\frac{3}{2}}-2 t^{2}, \text { where } 0 \leqslant t \leqslant 3
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 157, 144, 174]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 155, 609, 174]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the maximum velocity of \(P\) in the interval \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 704, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is given that in the interval \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 3\) the velocity of \(P\) is always positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 107, 144, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 106, 843, 123]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the distance of \(P\) from \(A\) at the instant when \(P\) is moving at this maximum velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 144]]<|/det|>
7 A particle \(P\) of mass 3 kg is projected with a speed of 8 m s \(^{-1}\) up a line of greatest slope of a rough plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. \(P\) is projected from a point \(A\) on the plane and comes to instantaneous rest at a point \(B\) on the plane. \(P\) then slides back down the plane. The coefficient of friction between \(P\) and the plane is \(\frac{1}{12} \sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 777, 181]]<|/det|>
Using an energy method throughout, find the speed of \(P\) at the instant it returns to \(A\).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
